bdy.p:
Lieutenant Colonel Doctor Roberto René Azurdia Paiz, is a
Guatemala n writer, diplomat and physician. Born in
Guatemala in 1926.

sec.p: He studied at the prestigious Escuela Politécnica Military Academy, and earned a scholarship to study medicine at the renowned Escuela Médico Militar in Mexico City.

He obtained his Medical Degree (MD) and returned to Guatemala to serve in that country’s Navy. He was appointed by the Navy as the Port Doctor for the Caribbean ports of Matias de Galvez and Puerto Barrios, and during his time as a doctor in those locations he helped eradicate malaria. The population in those areas suffered from plasmodium vivax and Falsiparum, which was caused by mosquitoes breeding in the multitude of swamps surrounding the tropical towns. Dr. Azurdia requested help from the government of Guatemala to perform blood tests on 28,000 local inhabitants, and from the World Health Organization (WHO) to vaccinate the populations, but the source of the infection—the mosquito—had to be destroyed, so he asked the captains of the freighters that visited those ports to donate their old engine oil to the military. The military, in turn, used the thousands of gallons of oil to create a protective layer of oil that was deposited on the surface water of all the swamps, effectively destroying the mosquito larvae in the area.

Another serious problem facing the population of the area was the lack of potable water. Serious gastrointestinal infections affected most of the population. Dr.Azurdia out of his own initiative wrote to Dr M.G. Candau of the World Health Organization asking for help. A water purification plant being shipped from Amsterdam to a city in Nigeria was re-routed because of a war in Nigeria, and sent to the Caribbean port in Guatemala instead. The plant was capable of producing potable water for up to one million people. It also benefited the economy of the ports because potable water was one necessity that was in very short supply in that area of the world and its availability increased the number of ships visiting the port to purchase provisions and water.

He was appointed Minister of Public Health by the
President of Guatemala
and served in that function until his nomination as Ambassador to Italy (Quirinale) in 1963 during the presidencies of
Enrique Peralta Azurdia
and Julio César Méndez Montenegro.

While acting as Ambassador to Italy, he served as representative from Guatemala to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Dr. Azurdia was co-founder of the Instituto Italo Latinoamericano (IILA) in Rome and governor of the Centro de Accion Latina, also in Rome, Italy.

After five years in Italy he was nominated Ambassador to
Panama and represented Guatemala in that country for nearly three years with the government of Omar Efraín Torrijos Herrera.

After serving in the Army of Guatemala where he ultimately attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, he retired from the military and moved to Mexico City, where he practiced medicine as a surgeon for twenty years.
Following his retirement from medicine, Dr. Azurdia developed a successful marble import/export business in Mexico City. He retired from business in 1995 and moved to the United States.
Dr. Azurdia has published numerous newspaper and magazine articles and is the author of the novel El Médico de Matías.
